binding.name: note
binding.literal: Style of Iznik pottery named after Abraham of Kutahya whose name is on a ewer in the BM reg no. G.1983.1. Objects were made in this style between circa 1490-1520.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A style of ivory carving, combining European and African features.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For artists working at any time in the area of the modern state of Austria. See also under GERMAN.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Bahu in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings associated with the court of Basohli, an offshoot of the Kulu royal house. The artists at Basohli developed a striking early painting style where the compositions were painted in bright colours and accentuated with luminous beetle wings cut out and pasted to the painted surface. These works are characterised by bold colour schemes, monochromatic backgrounds and exaggerated facial features through, for example, the shape of the eye. This vigorous bright style was retained until the early 18th century; later works include a more naturalistic landscape, and a softer colour palette.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term used for ceramics produced in Southern China for the Thai market, in the 18th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the work of late 19thC and 20thC Calcutta artists.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings from the court of Bikaner, the earliest of which date to the late sixteenth century. Bikaner rulers may have invited Mughal artists into their courtly retinue as early as the 17th century and instead of the traditional bold colour patterns and flat compositions, Bikaner artists started to experiment with a softer colour palette dominated by earth tones. Their figures were rendered more naturalistically through the use of shading and perspective. As a vassal of the Mughal empire, Bikaner rulers were also charged with running campaigns into the Deccan. Early Deccani influence in the luscious colouring and compositional format are also apparent.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Bilaspur in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery style after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This school flourished under the Shaybanid Dynasty.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to painting from the court of Bundi from the late sixteenth century to the early nineteenth century. Bundi was one of the earliest courts to accept Mughal rule when in 1569 the fort of Ranthambhor fell to the Mughal force. The earliest paintings from Bundi date to this period â namely the Chunar Ragamala, now dispersed.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Chamba in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to a wide range of drawings and paintings created by South Asian artists that were commissioned by European patrons, or intended for a European market. The subject matter is frequently descriptive of the âIndian Sceneâ and prepared in sets or albums. Works can be attributed to a variety of sub-styles dependent on the artistsâ regional training. The works often incorporate stylistic traits from both the South Asian and European traditions prevalent and popular in the region in the 18th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For artists working after 1992; otherwise use CZECHOSLOVAKIAN.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to paintings from Golconda, Bijapur, Ahmadnagar, Berar and Bidar, from the 16thC to the 18thC. The term 'Deccani School' should be entered in addition to any Narrower Terms where available.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to painting at the Mewari sub court between c. 1766â1850. The Devgarh style is an offshoot of the Udaipur court style and consists predominantly of portraits of the rulers (Rawats), genre scenes, and illustrations of the life of Krishna.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This applies to For Iron age objects which are decorated with La Tene motifs.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term was coined by Robert Skelton (in his unpublished lecture at SOAS, London, in 1974) and is now fairly widely accepted as a valid descriptive term for painting emerging from Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Malwa, Gujarat and the Rajasthani courts in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Garhwal in the Punjab Hills between the 17th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings from the court of Guler in the Punjab Hills. Paintings in this style tend to include elegant and undulating lines, prominent outlines, naturalistic landscape, and a soft colour palette.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: School of painting in Shiraz from 1330s to 1350s.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to either paintings from provincial centres in the style of the Isfahan School, or to copies or fakes of the Isfahan School.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term covers Arab, Turkish, Persian and Islamic Indian painting from 1200 to circa 1925.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to painting from the court of Jaipur in the eighteenth and early nineteenth century. The Kachhwaha clan of Jaipur were initially established at the nearby court of Amber, while Jaipur, a purpose-built city, was founded in 1728 by Raja Sawai Jai Singh II. The term can also be applied to earlier paintings from Amber, however the date should indicate if the work was painted before or after the move to Jaipur.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings created at the small court of Jammu in the Punjab Hills. The early works associated with Jammu are characterised by bold colour schemes, monochromatic backgrounds and exaggerated facial features. This vigorous bright style was retained until the early 18th century; later works include a more naturalistic landscape, and a softer colour palette.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects, mainly in P&E. See Japanese and its Narrow Terms for two-dimensional objects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings from the court of Jodhpur, capital of Marwar in the central desert region of Rajasthan. The earliest known painted works from Marwar is a Ragamala Series dated 1623. Stylistic traits often associated with Jodhpur include the sharply flaring skirt of the jama and thick mutton chop side-whiskers.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to porcelain of European manufacture, decorated to imitate Japanese Kakiemon porcelain (which was produced from the mid-17thC onwards). See also Kakiemon Ware in Ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a style of painting associated with the famous Kali temple in Calcutta known as the Kalighat temple. Sacred souvenirs in the form of paintings were produced here from the 1850s until the early decades of the 20th century.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings from Kangra. Little exists before the mid-18th century, however this relatively late flowering, created some astounding examples. The large state of Kangra extended from Nurpur and Chamba along its northern borders to Mandi in the east and the Punjab plains towards the south-west.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an artistic style associated with the medieval inhabitants of Cambodia; also represented in adjacent parts of Thailand. The Material Culture or Period term 'Khmer' should also be entered.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a painting style produced in the late 16thC produced in North-eastern Iran.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings from the court of Kishangarh from the seventeenth to the late eighteenth century. The rulers of Kishangarh were devotees of Lord Vishnu and his worship was a defining influence on the arts â images of the love dalliance between Krishna and Radha were often produced. Patronage of painting probably began under Man Singh (r. 1658-1706) in the Mughal style of Aurangzeb and elongated figures, with a slight arching of back, and oversized eyes became the norm.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to painting from the small court of Kota from the seventeenth century to the nineteenth century. The Mughals established Kota as an independent state from Bundi to be ruled by a branch of the family in 1631 and stylistically, the early art of Kota followed the Bundi model and concentrated on Ragamala and Baramasa painting. As it flourished in the eighteenth century there was a marked increase in the production of hunting scenes â tigers prowling dense jungles of tightly composed foliage, with hunters interspersed between the trees. The figures have a ruddier complexion in comparison to Bundi painting, with sculpturally modelled features.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A style of sundress from Malmalkot in Vanuatu

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to works from central India dating to the late 16th and early 17th century.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term used for a style of sculpture first produced under the kings of Burma who ruled from Mandalay (c.1850-1885). This style is remains popular today especially for Buddha images. These Buddha figures are characterised by a wide headband between the hair and forehead, a rounded usnisha, and an ornately pleated and folded robe. The inclusion of coloured and mirrored glass is also a distinctive feature.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to painting from the small court of Mandi in the Punjab Hills.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Small court of the Pahari Hills. The ruling family of Mankot were closely associated with Jammu (claiming descent from a Jammu raja and belonging to the Jammu Riasi family) yet they remained independent. The painting style associated with the court flourished in the 18th century. Episodes from the life of Krishna, as told through the 10th book of the Bhagavata Purana, were often illustrated.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the modern name given to the combined schools of painters Maruyama Okyo and Go Shun, which began in Kyoto in the late 18th century and spread to Osaka and Edo.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is a broad term that that encompasses the courtly style of Udaipur, as well as the sub court styles of Devgarh, Nathdwara, etc. This term should be used when the painting is the work of an Udaipur-trained artist, yet the patron is unknown.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term covers all objects dated from the 20thC onwards, made in the Middle East and North Africa or by artists originating from that region. North Africa includes Algeria, Morocco, Libya and Tunisia.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: Middle East and North Africa Modern Art

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This refers to a style of enamelling developed in centres in the Meuse Valley, but later adopted in workshops in the Middle Rhine, Champagne region, Ile de France and even England.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Mount Hagen Style from the Mount Hagen region, Papua New Guinea

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the Mughal style of painting, 1555-1800.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Painting from the pilgrimage site of Nathdvara revolved around the temple of Srinathji. Artists from as far away as Mewar, Kota, Ajmer and Delhi migrated to the centre in the eighteenth century to create images for travelling pilgrims and visiting nobles.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the work of a group of Indian painters of the post independence period who drew inspiration from the texts known as Tantras. Much of their work uses abstract and/or sexual imagery.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a Central American style alluding to provenance from the Nicoya Peninsula.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a Japanese school of painting with traditional themes, style and technique since the late nineteenth century.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term and its Narrow Terms are restricted to three-dimensional objects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to paintings produced in the Ottoman Empire from the 16thC to the late 19thC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings created in the small Rajput courts of the Punjab Hills. While the Pahari region was occupied from the 7th century onwards, with dated architectural monuments and temples, there is no evidence of painting until the mid-16th century. The painting tradition really flourished from the 17th to the 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Paintings used in story-telling by itinerant bards. Typical of the Andhra Pradesh/Karnataka border area and not - as was once thought - with the town of Paithan, further to the northwest. Although incorrect, this terminology is still in use (the mistaken provenance originally came about because early collections of these paintings were acquired in the town of Paithan). They are often double-sided, though in museum collections they have frequently been divided. Subjects include the epics, frequently with local characters and scenes interpolated. They are painted in a highly stylised manner and are clearly linked to the shadow-puppet tradition of Karnataka.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a transitional style in Archaic South Ionian pottery between Wild Goat and Fikellura.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a gold-working style in Columbia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to paintings that reflect the Mughal Painting Style but were presumably produced at provincial centres.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to works produced in Qajar Iran of the late 18thC and 19thC..

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to the court style of painting in Iran c.1550-1598.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'Rajasthan School' should be entered in addition to any Narrower Terms where available.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: District of Emilia-Romagna, south of Bologna: Faenza, Rimini, ForlÃ¬.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Style of design on Iznik pottery, referring to traditional arabesque (Islamic) patterns.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is restricted to three-dimensional objects.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a revival of traditional collaborative printmaking from the 1910s to the postwar period.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For artists working after 1992; see also CZECHOSLOVAKIAN.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a school of modern Japanese printmaking from about 1910, in which artists generally cut and print their own blocks in relatively small editions.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For the Company, Pahari, Rajasthan Schools, these terms are entered as well as the Narrower terms for Styles.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Chian pottery styles after Lemos 1991.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Berhnard Salin's first early Germanic animal style.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Berhnard Salin's second early Germanic animal style.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Berhnard Salin's third early Germanic animal style.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a style of painting from various centres in pre-Mughal India.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Style of island dress, originating in Tongoa island, Vanuatu.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to painting at the main court of Udaipur in Mewar, Rajasthan. When this term is used, the presumed patron is the Maharana. The earliest documented Mewar royal patronage of painting occurred in 1605 and the painting atelier continued to be active until the 20th century.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to paintings from the sub-court of Ujjain , a fiefdom of Bundi. The painting style is linked to the main court of Bundi and the artists commissioned by the Ujjain patrons may have in fact trained in Bundi.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to an Archaic Clazomenian pottery styles after Cook 1952.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to Jain painting dating to the mid to late sixteenth century. Jain merchants controlled the trade in this area of north India and were the predominant patrons of manuscripts between the twelfth and late fifteenth centuries. The majority of commissions were of illustrated religious texts, particularly the Kalpasutra. A conspicuous trait of Jain painting is the use of the further projecting eye; other defining traits include a thin and wiry line used to delineate figures shown most often in full profile, a complete lack of modelling, and architectural features used primarily as background motifs.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a Ming dynasty School of painting.
